awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Single droplet level understanding of phase inversion emulsification to enable continuous processing
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1604536
PI: Lee, Daeyeon

Emulsions are composed of liquid drops that are suspended in an immiscible liquid, such as oil drops in water. The drops are the dispersed phase, and the immiscible liquid is the continuous phase. Emulsions are used in the manufacture of many products, including foodstuffs, nutrients, drugs, and pesticides. Phase inversion emulsification (PIE) is a process for generating a new emulsion by inverting the phases of an existing emulsion.  PIE is especially useful when it is difficult to generate the desired emulsion by other methods. For example, Xerox uses PIE to manufacture latex particles, which are used to produce toners for printing and photocopying.  This GOALI project, which is a collaborative effort between the University of Pennsylvania and Xerox, will explore a variation on PIE called flow-induced PIE.  In flow-induced PIE, phase inversion takes place by flowing an existing emulsion through microchannels that contain abrupt variations in their cross-sections, such as constrictions or expansions. Under proper conditions, an emulsion of oil drops in water flowing through the channel is inverted into an emulsion of water drops in oil.  Experiments will be designed to explore effects of channel geometry, flow rates, wettability of the channel surface, and composition of the liquid phases on the phase inversion process. The flow-induced PIE process will allow products to be manufactured in a continuous process with reduced energy consumption, higher efficiency, and reduced environmental impact.  The project will provide opportunities for students at various academic levels to participate in research. Students from underrepresented groups will be encouraged to participate through several programs at Penn, including the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation.

A series of experiments will be conducted to determine effects of initial emulsion morphology and chemistry as well as channel geometry on the mechanism and efficiency of flow-induced PIE.  The effect of surface wettability of the channels on the phase inversion process will be determined.  Hydrodynamic parameters such as shear and extensional deformation in the microchannels will also be examined.  The use of a microfluidic platform will enable the formation of model emulsions with controlled properties and the direct observation of PIE during flow. Emulsion droplets with precisely controlled size, size distribution and interfacial chemistry will be used to understand effects of emulsion morphology and chemistry on flow-induced PIE. Alternative arrangements that can promote flow-induced PIE will also be explored, including flow through a microfluidic device containing pillar arrays, which serves as a model porous medium.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Emulsions are used for the fabrication of materials such as latex particles and porous materials and also used in the microencapsulation of active ingredients such as foodstuffs, nutrients, drugs, pesticides, genes and even living cells.  Phase inversion emulsification (PIE) is a process of generating an emulsion by inverting the continuous and dispersed phases of a pre-existing emulsion. PIE is a particularly useful method to prepare emulsions when it is challenging to directly generate the target emulsion via conventional methods. Most, if not all, PIE processes in industry are currently performed as batch processes. Cost reduction and more efficient use of the equipment and floor space are strong motivators for shift of industrial processes towards continuous mode. To enable such a shift, we investigated an under-explored flow-induced PIE (FIPIE) technique. In FIPIE, the energy required to overcome the energy barrier to PIE is provided through deformation of emulsions as they flow through precisely engineered conduits. The main objective of this proposal was to investigate FIPIE at the single droplet level using microfluidic devices and to obtain fundamental knowledge that will enable continuous PIE processes in industry. We investigated the effect of the geometry of channels as well as flow conditions on the FIPIE. We showed emulsions can be induced to undergo FIPIE if they are flowed through a tapered channel that widens abruptly. We found that there is a specific set of geometry and flow conditions that induce PIE under flow. We have also shown that the chemistry of surfactant that stabilizes the emulsions has a strong influence on the FIPIE.  We developed a new method of inducing PIE by taking advantage of complexation between a polyelectrolyte and a surfactant. This new method overcomes the need for developing a new surfactant chemistry to enable PIE. Moveover, this method can be adapted to use environmentally friendly materials. We believe our results will contribute to enabling continuous FIPIE, which will significantly lower the energy consumption of the process and also enable higher efficiency.  Such a process can be especially beneficial for the pharmaceutical as well as food industry that are aggressively pursuing continuous process in place of batch operations and also by using environmentally friendly materials. The research project benefited from active involvement of graduate and undergraduate students, and through the mentorship by the co-PIs from the industry. Graduate students supported on this project interacted on a regular basis with the industry mentors. Moreover, this project provided several undergraduate students from Penn and other institutions with excellent research experiences. Female undergraduate students from underrepresented minority groups have been mentored by the graduate students that were supported by this grant. Multiple students in the PI?s group also developed scientific modules for local secondary schools during the COVID pandemic, promoting STEM education.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2021
Modified by: Daeyeon Lee
